reading.passage: Evidence-based description is a core academic skill. When describing a photo or a scene, strong speakers separate observation from interpretation. Observation focuses on what can be verified directly from the image, while interpretation uses cautious language to propose what might be happening.

questions.question: What is the best overall description of 'Commuters on Public Transportation'?
choices: A calm indoor meeting with formal presentations
People in a public setting engaged in an everyday activity
A private ceremony with an audience and a stage
A laboratory experiment with specialized equipment
questions.explanation: The scene title and context point to a public setting and routine activity rather than a formal ceremony, lab, or meeting.

questions.question: Which phrase is best for avoiding an unsupported guess?

questions.question: Which connector best signals a contrast between two ideas?

listening.note: Read this as a script and practice note-taking.
listening.script: Today we will practice describing a photo. First, list what you can see. Second, explain what it might mean. Finally, connect it to a broader idea.

speakingTasks.prompt: Describe the scene in 'Commuters on Public Transportation'. What do you notice first?
Explain how the setting in 'Commuters on Public Transportation' affects the mood of the people.
Predict what might happen next in 'Commuters on Public Transportation' and give one reason.

writingTasks.prompt: Write a short description of the photo and summarize the main mood in 'Commuters on Public Transportation'.
Explain the relationship between the people and the setting in 'Commuters on Public Transportation'. Use at least two specific details.
writingTasks.sampleAnswer: In 'Commuters on Public Transportation', the setting provides clear context for the people’s actions. Overall, the scene feels purposeful because the subjects seem engaged and oriented toward a shared goal. For example, their body language suggests focus, and the environment appears to support that activity. As a result, the mood is more organized than casual, which indicates that the moment is part of a routine rather than a spontaneous event.

writingTasks.prompt: Some people prefer busy environments, while others prefer quiet ones. Using 'Commuters on Public Transportation' as inspiration, state your preference and support it with reasons.
writingTasks.sampleAnswer: I prefer quieter environments because they help me think clearly and work efficiently. In contrast, busy places can be distracting and make it harder to focus. For example, when I study in a calm space, I can organize my ideas and finish tasks faster. A possible explanation is that fewer interruptions reduce mental fatigue. Overall, choosing a quiet environment leads to better concentration and less stress, which improves my performance.

examTips: Start with a one-sentence overview before details.
Use location phrases (foreground/background) to organize your description.
Avoid guessing; hedge with 'it appears' or 'it is likely'.
Include 2–3 specific details (objects, actions, setting) to support ideas.
Use linking words (overall, in contrast, as a result) for coherence.
Speak steadily and manage time: plan 5 seconds, speak 40–45 seconds.

sceneNotes: Focus on what you can SEE (people, setting, actions).

grammar.rule: برای توصیف کاری که **همین الان** در تصویر اتفاق می‌افتد از **am/is/are + V‑ing** استفاده کن.

grammar.title: Comparatives (صفت‌های تفضیلی)

proDescriptions.label: Academic Description
proDescriptions.text: The image portrays inside a subway car: passengers seated and standing, most looking at their phones; one person holds a metal pole. Visual elements such as lighting, posture, and setting provide contextual cues that support an interpretation of mood and purpose. The composition balances foreground action with background environment to communicate a clear everyday scenario.

proDescriptions.label: Narrative Style
proDescriptions.text: The moment feels frozen in time: Inside a subway car, passengers sit on both sides while others stand and hold metal poles. Small details—light, movement, and expressions—turn an ordinary scene into a memorable snapshot.

scenarios.en: Last weekend, I found myself at Subway/metro car. Passengers sit and stand in a bright subway car, many focused on their phones. At first, I noticed Subway seats, Handrails, Smartphones and the way people were sitting/standing. Then I looked closer: their clothing (Mixed everyday clothes (jackets, shirts, backpacks)) and their expressions made the scene feel tired, neutral, focused on screens. After that, something small happened that changed the mood, and we had to respond quickly. In the end, we solved it, and the moment became a story I still remember.
scenarios.fa: آخرِ هفته‌ی قبل Subway/metro car بودم. Passengers sit and stand in a bright subway car, many focused on their phones. اول Subway seats، Handrails و Smartphones را دیدم و اینکه آدم‌ها چطور Sitting/standing. بعد دقیق‌تر نگاه کردم: لباس‌ها (Mixed everyday clothes (jackets, shirts, backpacks)) و حالت چهره‌ها باعث شد فضا Tired، Neutral و Focused on screens به نظر برسد. بعدش یک اتفاق کوچک افتاد که حال‌وهوا را عوض کرد و مجبور شدیم سریع واکنش نشان بدهیم. آخرش حلش کردیم و همان لحظه تبدیل شد به خاطره‌ای که هنوز یادم می‌ماند.

grammarUsed.en: Past simple with time marker (last weekend) and sequencing (at first/then/after that/in the end).
grammarUsed.fa: گذشته ساده با قید زمان و ترتیب رخدادها (اول/بعد/بعدش/آخرش).

en.tense: Past Simple (V2) to tell a short memory, plus sequencing words (first/then/finally).
sentenceStructure: Time markers: yesterday / last week / a few minutes ago.
howToBuild: Start with a time phrase: Yesterday, Last weekend, A few minutes ago…
Change the main action into past simple (reviewed, chose, played…).
Use sequencing words to make a clear story: first, then, after that, finally.
End with a result or feeling: Everyone felt… / It turned out…
examples: Yesterday, they sitting/standed.
Then, they checked Subway seats and continued.
Finally, they felt Tired about the outcome.

fa.tense: گذشته ساده (Past Simple) برای تعریف یک خاطره کوتاه، همراه با کلمات ترتیب‌دهنده (first/then/finally).
sentenceStructure: عبارات زمانی: yesterday / last week / a few minutes ago
howToBuild: با یک عبارت زمانی شروع کن: Yesterday, Last weekend, A few minutes ago…
فعل اصلی را به گذشته ساده تبدیل کن (reviewed, chose, played…).
از کلمات ترتیب‌دهنده استفاده کن: first, then, after that, finally.
با نتیجه یا حس تمام کن: Everyone felt… / It turned out…
examples: دیروز، They sitting/standed.
بعد، They Subway seats را بررسی کرد و ادامه داد.
در نهایت، آن‌ها درباره نتیجه Tired بودند.

scenarios.title: Reflection
scenarios.en: Over the past few months, I have started paying attention to scenes like this. I have noticed that details such as Subway seats, Handrails, Smartphones, Bags are not background; they guide the story. I have also learned how actions like using smartphones can signal feelings such as tired, neutral, focused on screens. Since then, I have taken more time to observe before I speak, and my descriptions have become clearer and more specific.
scenarios.fa: در چند ماه گذشته شروع کرده‌ام به صحنه‌هایی مثل این بیشتر دقت کنم. متوجه شده‌ام جزئیاتی مثل Subway seats، Handrails، Smartphones و Bags فقط «پس‌زمینه» نیستند؛ آن‌ها مسیر داستان را تعیین می‌کنند. همچنین یاد گرفته‌ام کارهایی مثل Using smartphones چطور می‌تواند احساساتی مثل Tired، Neutral و Focused on screens را نشان بدهد. از آن زمان بیشتر قبل از حرف زدن مشاهده می‌کنم و توصیف‌هایم واضح‌تر و دقیق‌تر شده است.

grammarUsed.en: Present perfect to connect past learning to the present, plus since/over the past to frame experience.
grammarUsed.fa: حال کامل برای وصل کردن یادگیری گذشته به حال، همراه با «در چند ماه گذشته/از آن زمان».

en.tense: Present Perfect (have/has + past participle) to connect past experience to the present; use since/for/already/yet.
howToBuild: Say what has happened up to now (experience/result).
Use since (a starting point) or for (a duration).
Add a contrast or reflection: however, although, even though.
Finish with what they are doing now (present continuous) if needed.
examples: They have already handled similar situations before.
They have learned to stay Tired in Subway/metro car.
Although it looks routine, the details have mattered.

fa.tense: حال کامل (have/has + شکل سوم فعل) برای ربط دادن گذشته به حال؛ همراه با since/for/already/yet.
howToBuild: بگو تا همین الآن چه تجربه/نتیجه‌ای اتفاق افتاده.
از since (نقطه شروع) یا for (مدت زمان) استفاده کن.
یک جمله‌ی بازتاب/تضاد اضافه کن: however, although, even though.
اگر لازم شد با یک جمله حال استمراری وضعیت الآن را بگو.
examples: They قبلاً موقعیت‌های مشابهی را تجربه کرده است.
They یاد گرفته است در Subway/metro car Tired بماند.
اگرچه کار روتین به نظر می‌رسد، جزئیات مهم بوده‌اند.

scenarios.title: A challenge
scenarios.en: If we were to replay this moment at Subway/metro car, one small change could create a big problem. If Subway seats, Handrails had been missing or damaged, we would have had to improvise. Someone might have said, “We should slow down and check,” and another person could have replied that we were running out of time. In a situation like this, we should prioritize safety and clarity, even if it means changing the plan. If I had ignored those details, I might have misunderstood the whole scene.
scenarios.fa: اگر قرار بود این لحظه در Subway/metro car دوباره تکرار شود، یک تغییر کوچک می‌توانست یک مشکل بزرگ بسازد. اگر Subway seats و Handrails نبود یا آسیب دیده بود، مجبور می‌شدیم بداهه تصمیم بگیریم. ممکن بود کسی بگوید «باید آهسته‌تر برویم و بررسی کنیم» و نفر دیگری جواب بدهد که وقت کم داریم. در چنین موقعیتی بهتر است ایمنی و شفافیت را در اولویت بگذاریم، حتی اگر مجبور شویم برنامه را تغییر بدهیم. اگر آن جزئیات را نادیده می‌گرفتم، شاید کل صحنه را اشتباه می‌فهمیدم.

grammarUsed.en: Conditionals for hypotheticals, modals for advice/possibility, and short reported speech (might have said/could have replied).
grammarUsed.fa: شرطی‌ها برای موقعیت فرضی، افعال کمکی برای امکان/پیشنهاد، و نقل‌قول غیرمستقیم برای بازگویی گفت‌وگو.

en.tense: Mixed grammar for higher-level storytelling: conditionals, modals (might/must), and reported speech.
sentenceStructure: Second conditional: If + past simple, would + base verb.
Third conditional: If + had + V3, would have + V3.
Modals of deduction: might/must/can't + base verb.
Reported speech: He said (that) … / She asked if …
howToBuild: Describe the challenge and add a hypothetical solution (If…, would…).
Use modals to infer causes from the photo (They might…, It must…).
Add reported speech for realism: Someone said that…
Finish with a consequence or lesson learned.
examples: If they had checked Subway seats earlier, they would have avoided a mistake.
They might be under pressure, but they must stay Tired.
The supervisor said that every detail mattered.

fa.tense: گرامر ترکیبی سطح بالا: شرطی‌ها، افعال کمکی (might/must) و نقل قول غیرمستقیم (reported speech).
sentenceStructure: شرطی نوع دوم: If + past simple, would + فعل ساده.
شرطی نوع سوم: If + had + V3, would have + V3.
نقل قول غیرمستقیم: He said (that)… / She asked if…
howToBuild: چالش را بگو و یک راه‌حل فرضی اضافه کن (If…, would…).
با مدال‌ها درباره علت‌ها حدس بزن (might/must).
برای واقعی‌تر شدن از reported speech استفاده کن.
در پایان نتیجه یا درسِ داستان را بگو.
examples: اگر They زودتر Subway seats را چک کرده بود، اشتباه را جلوگیری می‌کرد.
ممکن است تحت فشار باشند، اما باید Tired بمانند.
سرپرست گفت که هر جزئیاتی مهم است.
